title: Dragons' Den Series 22 – Accessibility meets innovation with Snowball

content.text: Series 22 of Dragons’ Den was full to the brim with keen entrepreneurs with IP  portfolios. We followed the highs and lows with excitement as hopeful business owners entered the Den. We hope that they all left with something – be it investment, advice or exposure of their business to the show’s audience.
Following the conclusion of the series, we’re reflecting on some of the pitches that we haven’t yet featured on our blog channel but were rich with  IP.
One such business is Snowball, an accessibility app designed to make life easier for those with both visible and hidden disabilities.
The snowball effect

Simon Sansome, founder of Snowball Community Limited, entered the Den looking for £80,000 in exchange for a 15% stake in the business that is, as he describes it “an advanced version of Tripadvisor for the disabled community”. The app allows users to leave reviews about the accessibility of a variety of locations including retail, transport, recreational activities and more, allowing other users to find spots that cater to their needs.

Like many great inventions, Snowball was created out of necessity. After a life-altering injury, Simon discovered how inaccessible many places were - and that no platform existed to share accessibility information. The idea for Snowball was born.

As Simon continued through his pitch, his passion for the product was evident –  as was the capacity of the app. He mentions that Google Maps, Fuel Service and Toilet Map are just a few of the sites that feed data into Snowball, expanding its capability.
I know how useful apps such as these can be, and having family members with access requirements means that Snowball could be a game changer when planning trips.
What’s in a name?

Sara Davies was the first with questions for the founder, diving into the origin of the brand name. Simon explained that the name Snowball doesn’t mean anything - and that’s intentional. In his experience, he’s found that brands  aimed towards people with disabilities can seem discriminatory, often towards those with a hidden disability, hence choosing a generic name.
Steven Bartlett even chimed in that he liked the brand name - a rare seal of approval as he admits to Simon that he usually doesn’t like branding brought into the Den.

A quick search on our ‘Search for a trade mark’ tool shows that Simon has, wisely, protected his logo with a trade mark  (UK00003831578). You can file for a trade mark yourself or you can use an IP Attorney, and can find out more about trade marks on our website.
This protection is something that founder Simon Sansome values:
Where there’s a will, there’s a Waze

Peter Jones’ ears pricked up when discussions over Simon’s work with Google began. The business mogul with a portfolio of tech businesses drew comparisons between Simon’s business model to that of Waze®, a navigational app that operates on user data and has reached global success.

The transfer of data that Simon discusses and his developing relationship with Google likely means there will have been an involvement of Non-disclosure agreements (NDAs). An NDA is a legal contract that sets out how you share information or ideas in confidence. You can read more about NDAs and find some examples on our site.
Decision time in the Den

As Peter  realised the potential global scale for the app, he was the first to make an offer. Peter offered Simon the full £80,000 he had asked for in return for 25% of the business – but perhaps sensing that the rest of the Den would be hot on his heels, also invited his fellow Dragons to share the deal with him. The remaining four Dragons jumped at the opportunity, including Deborah Meaden who mentions the challenges that her sister, a wheelchair user, faces.

With each Dragon taking 5% in return for a £16,000 investment, Simon became a little teary-eyed at the full house of offers. I must say he wasn't the only one- the emotion certainly got to me after such a heartfelt pitch!
Simon accepted the offers and left the Den with five Dragons on his side-and no doubt plenty of new users of his app across the country after the airing of this episode.
